articles.headline: China Ends Wuhan Lockdown, but Normal Life Is a Distant Dream
articles.snippet: In the city where the coronavirus outbreak was first reported, the reopening of outbound travel won’t end hard times, wariness or confinement.
articles.abstract: In the city where the coronavirus outbreak was first reported, the reopening of outbound travel won’t end hard times, wariness or confinement.
articles.lead_paragraph: China on Wednesday ended its lockdown of Wuhan, the city where the coronavirus first emerged and a potent symbol in a pandemic that has killed tens of thousands of people, shaken the global economy and thrown daily life into upheaval across the planet.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Vivian Wang

articles.headline: Trump Ousts Pandemic Spending Watchdog Known for Independence
articles.snippet: The official had been leading the office of the inspector general for the Pentagon. In removing him from that role, the president stripped him of his pandemic relief oversight duties as well.
articles.abstract: The official had been leading the office of the inspector general for the Pentagon. In removing him from that role, the president stripped him of his pandemic relief oversight duties as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump moved on Tuesday to oust the leader of a new watchdog panel charged with overseeing how his administration spends trillions of taxpayer dollars in coronavirus pandemic relief, the latest step in an abruptly unfolding White House power play against semi-independent inspectors general across the government.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Peter Baker

articles.headline: ‘I Just Need the Comfort’: Processed Foods Make a Pandemic Comeback
articles.snippet: Shoppers, moved by nostalgia and hunting for longer shelf lives, are returning to old standbys like Chef Boyardee and Campbell’s soup.
articles.abstract: Shoppers, moved by nostalgia and hunting for longer shelf lives, are returning to old standbys like Chef Boyardee and Campbell’s soup.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few months ago, Sue Smith considered herself a healthy eater. She ate salads with kale and quinoa. She counted calories. She eliminated processed sugar from her diet. She avoided dairy products.

articles.headline: Small Business Aid Program Stretches Agency to Its Limits
articles.snippet: The Small Business Administration is not equipped to handle the demand for emergency loans. It is trying to fix aging systems, but the delays are rattling banks and small businesses.
articles.abstract: The Small Business Administration is not equipped to handle the demand for emergency loans. It is trying to fix aging systems, but the delays are rattling banks and small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five days after the start of a $349 billion emergency effort to get money into the hands of small businesses, the agency at the heart of the program is emerging as its biggest bottleneck.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, David McCabe and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Voting in Wisconsin During a Pandemic: Lines, Masks and Plenty of Fear
articles.snippet: Wisconsin’s primary showed an electoral system stretched to the breaking point by the coronavirus crisis, as people weighed the health risks against their desire to vote.
articles.abstract: Wisconsin’s primary showed an electoral system stretched to the breaking point by the coronavirus crisis, as people weighed the health risks against their desire to vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Even before voting began, there were lines outside polling locations that stretched for several blocks. Some poll workers wore hazmat suits. Nearly every voter wore a face mask, removing it only to make small talk that reflected a combination of determination and grim humor about the extraordinary experience of voting amid a deadly pandemic.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: 31% Can’t Pay the Rent: ‘It’s Only Going to Get Worse’
articles.snippet: As the economic shutdown pares tenants’ incomes, April payments have been reduced, deferred or withheld. Some landlords see their property at risk.
articles.abstract: As the economic shutdown pares tenants’ incomes, April payments have been reduced, deferred or withheld. Some landlords see their property at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: First it was the waitress whose restaurant closed. Then the waiter, the bartender, the substitute teacher, the hairdresser, the tattoo artist and the Walgreens manager.

articles.headline: Eight U.K. Doctors Died From Coronavirus. All Were Immigrants.
articles.snippet: In a country where anti-immigrant sentiment gave rise to the Brexit movement, Britain’s health care system depends heavily on foreign doctors, who are now on the front lines fighting the epidemic.
articles.abstract: In a country where anti-immigrant sentiment gave rise to the Brexit movement, Britain’s health care system depends heavily on foreign doctors, who are now on the front lines fighting the epidemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The eight men moved to Britain from different corners of its former empire, all of them doctors or doctors-to-be, becoming foot soldiers in the effort to build a free universal health service after World War II.

articles.headline: Uber and Lyft Drivers Face Hurdles to Stimulus Bill Benefits
articles.snippet: Gig workers seemingly eligible for unemployment pay because of the pandemic have met roadblocks to filing. Some fault Labor Department rules.
articles.abstract: Gig workers seemingly eligible for unemployment pay because of the pandemic have met roadblocks to filing. Some fault Labor Department rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Senate approved a huge stimulus bill in late March that made gig workers and other contractors eligible for unemployment assistance during the coronavirus pandemic, Uber’s chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, rejoiced on Twitter.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Drops Out of 2020 Democratic Race for President
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders, a democratic socialist making his second run for the White House, withdrew after a series of losses to Joseph R. Biden Jr., who emerges as the presumptive nominee for the general election.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders, a democratic socialist making his second run for the White House, withdrew after a series of losses to Joseph R. Biden Jr., who emerges as the presumptive nominee for the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont ended his presidential candidacy on Wednesday, concluding a quest that elevated him as a standard-bearer of American liberalism and clearing the way for a general election between the presumptive Democratic nominee, Joseph R. Biden Jr., and President Trump at a time of national crisis.
